title: 111_hr5006
content: The Act may be cited as the "White House Conference on Haiti Act of 2010". Congress acknowledges Haiti as the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere and the devastating impact of the 7.0 magnitude earthquake that struck on January 12, 2010. The earthquake caused widespread destruction, affecting an estimated 3,000,000 people, with many at risk of long-term displacement and vulnerability. Haiti was already recovering from previous natural disasters and food shortages before the earthquake. President Obama pledged unwavering support and a coordinated effort to aid in Haiti's recovery. President Obama pledged unwavering support and a coordinated effort to save lives and support recovery in Haiti. There were approximately 10,000 NGOs operating in Haiti before the earthquake, and at least 3,000,000 Haitians live abroad, providing significant capital through remittances. The global community has responded positively to the tragedy, with individuals, businesses, and organizations offering support. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF THE CONFERENCE. The President must call the White House Conference on Haiti by December 31, 2010, to make policy recommendations for Haiti's recovery. The Secretary of State and Homeland Security will plan the Conference to address ongoing challenges, promote collaboration, and identify gaps in humanitarian assistance. The White House Conference on Haiti aims to bring together various stakeholders to identify gaps in humanitarian assistance, share best practices in development assistance, and propose innovative ideas for sustainable rebuilding in Haiti. It also seeks to review existing policies and initiatives for long-term economic growth in Haiti, explore opportunities for greater involvement by the Haitian diaspora and private sector, and suggest possible changes to US immigration, trade, and foreign aid policies to aid in Haiti's recovery. SEC. 4. POLICY COMMITTEE; RELATED COMMITTEES. Established by June 30, 2010, the Policy Committee consists of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Members include officers or employees of the United States and individuals experienced in disaster relief and development in other countries. The Policy Committee, established in 2010, consists of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Members are selected by majority and minority leaders of the House and Senate, with consultation from relevant committees. The Committee acts by majority vote. The Policy Committee, established in 2010, consists of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Members are selected by the minority leader of the Senate, after consultation with relevant committees. The Committee acts by majority vote, with the Under Secretary of State for Public Diplomacy and Public Affairs serving as the chairperson. The Policy Committee's duties include making recommendations for the timely convening of the Conference and submitting a proposed agenda to the Co-chairs. The Policy Committee, established in 2010, consists of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The Committee, chaired by the Under Secretary of State for Public Diplomacy and Public Affairs, is responsible for making recommendations for the timely convening of the Conference, submitting a proposed agenda, recommending delegates, determining the number of delegates, and establishing an executive committee. SEC. 5. CONFERENCE DELEGATES. The Co-chairs will bring together delegates from various fields without political affiliation, including representatives of governments, the Haitian diaspora, NGOs, and private sector entities. SEC. 6. CONFERENCE ADMINISTRATION. In administering this section, the Co-chairs shall provide notice to all Policy Committee members of meetings, request cooperation from other federal departments, make proposed agendas public, provide background materials, and hire additional personnel as needed. The Co-chairs may employ additional personnel as needed without following standard appointment procedures, ensure the proposed agenda is published in the Federal Register within 30 days, appoint personnel without political bias, and prevent inappropriate influence on Conference recommendations. The Co-chairs of the Conference may accept gifts to carry out the Act, including cash or in-kind donations and voluntary services. These gifts are in addition to any allocated amounts. The Co-chairs of the Conference may accept gifts (cash or in kind) on behalf of the United States to carry out the Act. Gifts are available in addition to allocated amounts and may be earmarked for specific purposes. The Co-chairs must maintain records of sources, amounts, and uses of gifts, as well as the recipients of assistance and the amount received by each. SEC. 7. REPORT OF THE CONFERENCE. The Policy Committee will prepare a preliminary report on the Conference within 100 days of adjournment, to be published in the Federal Register and submitted to Members of Congress and administration officials. A final report, including views and findings of Members of Congress and administration officials, will be prepared within 6 months and recommendations for administrative action and legislation will be transmitted to the President and Congress. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS. The Under Secretary of State for Public Diplomacy and Public Affairs will prepare and publish status reports on the implementation of recommendations from the final report within 1 year of the Conference adjournment. The Comptroller General will also prepare subsequent status reports every 5 years until all recommendations are achieved. The Committees on Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives and the Senate will hold hearings on recommendations and status reports regarding Haiti's recovery and long-term development. These hearings are enacted as an exercise of rulemaking authority, allowing for changes to be made to the rules of the House or Senate as needed. The Committees on Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives and the Senate will hold hearings on Haiti's recovery and development. Rules can be changed by either House at any time, similar to any other rule. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization is granted for necessary sums to carry out the Act, with limitations on new spending authority. Funds appropriated or received as gifts shall be available for one year after the Conference adjourns. Funds authorized under section 6(c) must be obligated or expended within 1 year after the Conference adjourns. Any unobligated funds after this period will be returned to the Treasury, unless a trust fund is established for a future Conference on Haiti if the Conference is not convened before December 31, 2010.
